Bemidji's annual 'March for Life' held Saturday
More than 150 people participated in a pro-life march held on Saturday, Jan. 22, in Bemidji. 










Bemidji 'March for Life' participants carried signs through town during the annual event on Saturday, Jan. 22, 2022. Contributed. 








By
Pioneer Staff Report

January 24, 2022 at 4:06 PM






        Share
    



Share this article
















BEMIDJI -- More than 150 people participated in a pro-life march held on Saturday, Jan. 22, in Bemidji. According to a release, the event started at the Beltrami County Courthouse and began with an invocation by Gregg Claypool for an end to abortion. 








About 150 participated in a pro-life march held on Saturday, Jan. 23, in Bemidji.Contributed. 



After the march, attendees gathered at St. Philip's Catholic Church for a soup and sandwich lunch served by the Bemidji Council 1544 of the Knights of Columbus. During the lunch, participants heard a testimony from Father Michael Arey, the release said. The event is held annually in protest of the Roe vs. Wade 1973 U.S. Supreme Courts decision legalizing abortion," the release said. "This was the 48th anniversary of the decision. Over 62 million abortions have been reported since then." 








Bemidji's annual 'March for Life' event started at the Beltrami County Courthouse on Saturday, Jan. 22, 2022. Contributed. 



"The event, along with the Washington D.C. March for Life, has been held since 1974 as a peaceful protest to the Supreme Court Roe v. Wade decision of Jan. 22, 1973, legalizing abortion in the United States," the release said.
